item.title: Best Ways To Get Salvaged Metal And Fuel Cells In Dune: Awakening
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/best-ways-to-get-salvaged-metal-and-fuel-cells-in-dune-awakening/1100-6532156/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

During the early stages of Dune: Awakening, you'll be tasked with acquiring a few basic resources that will serve as the foundation of your character's gear and base items. Some of these resources include Granite, Plant Fiber, and Salvaged Metal. You'll also be asked to add some Fuel Cells to your inventory, as those are what you use to power anything electronic in Dune: Awakening.

When it comes to Granite and Plant Fiber, you'll have no issues whatsoever finding either of those resources, as they're as abundant as the sand on Arrakis. However, Salvaged Metal and Fuel Cells take a little more searching to find. Below, you can see exactly how to get Salvaged Metal and Fuel Cells for all of your early game needs in Dune: Awakening.

Where to find Salvaged Metal in Dune: Awakening

Out of the two resources, Salvaged Metal is the easier one to find. One of your first missions in Dune: Awakening requires you to find 250 of the resource, though, which isn't so easy.

Salvaged Metal can be looted as a single item all around the starting area of Dune: Awakening. It looks like a small metal box that's usually lying on the sand near rocky formations. Of course, while you can pick up a few of these pieces, that's not going to get you nearly close to the amount you need.

The best way to acquire Salvaged Metal in large quantities is by raiding scavenger camps in the starting region of the game. All around you are small camps, either inside moisture-sealed caves or underneath some rocky cover, that can be looted for solid amounts of Salvaged Metal. Of course, these camps aren't unoccupied, so you'll have to kill scavengers to get your hands on the resource.

When you're looting a camp, you can find the singular pieces of Salvaged Metal on the ground, but you can also cut open larger pieces of it using your Cutteray. This is the same item you use to cut open Granite Stone boulders, Copper Ore, etc. Scan large pieces of metal with a yellow icon above them, cut where the blue mark is, and you'll loot roughly 40-60 pieces of Salvaged Metal.

You can also find these large metal pieces out in the world next to singular pieces, but they're far more common to find at camps. Salvaged Metal can be looted in chests at camps as well, but those chests usually have rarer items inside them. You might even find some water in these chests, which is as valuable an item as you can have in Dune: Awakening.

To find a scavenger camp, just open your map and zoom in. Hover over all of the icons to see which ones are camps. You can discover every camp for yourself by eventually crafting a Survey Probe in Dune: Awakening, but that only comes after you make Copper Ingots at a Fabricator inside your base once you complete your first trial mission.

Where to find Fuel Cells in Dune: Awakening

Unfortunately, Fuel Cells are often located in the same areas as Salvaged Metal, but they're found in far fewer numbers. Fuel Cells look like small, rectangular cartridges on the ground, and you can often find them lying right next to Salvaged Metal pieces.

Instead of looking on the ground for Fuel Cells, though, you want to find scavenger camps with chests in them. Chests have a high chance of containing Fuel Cells and other rarer items, so looting them is one of the most consistent ways to acquire the resource.

To make your Fuel Cell farming process even better, chests at camps, as well as all world resources, are on a respawn timer in Dune: Awakening. After one in-game day, every item, enemy, resource, and chest in the world and at camps will respawn, allowing you to loot everything over again. If you find a route with plenty of scavenger camps on it, you can make a few runs within a couple of hours and stock up on every resource you might need.

Scavenger camps and world looting aren't the only ways to acquire Fuel Cells, though. You can also head up to trader camps, like the one at the Griffin Research Tradepost, and purchase Fuel Cells for money. While this isn't the most efficient way to acquire the resource, spending 50 Solari per Fuel Cell isn't a bad fee if you need them in a pinch.

As you progress in Dune: Awakening, you'll find more trader camps and more ways of acquiring both Fuel Cells and Salvaged Metal. However, for the early game, stick to scavenger camps, traders, and simple world looting.

item.title: This Call Of Duty Skin Is Broken And Temporarily Removed
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/this-call-of-duty-skin-is-broken-and-temporarily-removed/1100-6532174/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Call of Duty's Season 4 update has seemingly caused a problem with an operator skin for Frank Woods, and players will find the skin is currently unavailable to use in both Black Ops 6 and Warzone.

According to Treyarch's Trello board, the developer disabled the "Numbers" operator skin for Frank Woods on May 31, which is just days after the Season 4 update. Treyarch is investigating a bug that caused this operator skin to glow much brighter than intended.

The Numbers skin was part of the "Frank Woods Operator Pack," which was a preorder bonus given out to those who preordered the digital or Vault edition of Call of Duty: Black Ops 6. The Numbers skin featured Woods surrounded by glowing red numbers, but it appears a bug from the recent update caused his entire body to have an intense glow.

The developer says this is just a temporary removal. Players who try to use the Numbers skin during this time will spawn in as the default Woods skin instead. This is an ongoing investigation, so there's currently no date given for when the skin will return. The Season 4 update had a rough launch, including buggy multiplayer lobbies and Warzone server issues.

Currently, Call of Duty features a crossover event with the Ballerina movie, which is part of the John Wick universe. Players can earn free cosmetics and unlock a new marksman rifle during the Ballerina event in Black Ops 6 and Warzone. The movie's Eve Macarro also has an operator bundle available in Call of Duty's in-game shop.

Dune: Awakening arrives June 10 for standard edition players, but for those with the deluxe edition, the game launched Thursday. Coinciding with the head-start release is some in-game loot that you can earn via Twitch Drops. The Twitch campaign runs until June 24, with three items up for grabs to help with your base defenses. To get these items, you will need to watch Twitch streams of Dune: Awakening, where the creator has drops enabled.

Dune: Awakening Twitch Rewards

As shown in the image above, the three rewards up for grabs are: observer foundation, observer floor, and the observer wall. Each of these requires that you watch eligible Twitch streams for a specific amount of time and can only be earned on one stream at a time.

You can check your eligibility for Twitch Drops by navigating to your profile icon on Twitch and selecting Drops and Rewards in the dropdown menu. If your account isn't already connected, there is a connect option in the Drops and Rewards screen, which will take you to the game's website where you can connect from there.

item.title: The Nintendo Switch Online GameCube Controller Supports Gyro Controls
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/the-nintendo-switch-online-gamecube-controller-supports-gyro-controls/1100-6532159/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Now that the Nintendo Switch 2 and its initial wave of accessories have made it into fans' hands, players have been surprised to discover that Nintendo's GameCube controller for the Switch 2 supports gyro controls.

The new controller, available exclusively through Nintendo Switch Online and at select physical Nintendo stores, looks almost exactly like an original GameCube controller but features some key upgrades. The original c-stick doubles as the Switch 2's new C-button, which will open GameChat, and the internals have been re-arranged for a more responsive d-pad, according to a parts breakdown on Reddit.

Now Playing: Nintendo GameCube Classics – Official Reveal Trailer | Nintendo Switch 2

The most surprising new addition is the gyroscope, which wasn't mentioned by Nintendo in the lead-up to the Switch 2's release. Surprised fans instead discovered the added functionality themselves upon unboxing the new controller--such as Japanese Splatoon content creator Sashibu, who posted to X about the new option to play Splatoon with a GameCube controller.

Gyroscopic controls were first introduced to mainstream gaming with the Wii MotionPlus in 2009, and have remained in use by Nintendo in each of their consoles since. A decent number of Switch titles make use of gyroscopic controls for aiming (the Wii and Wii U both made us of a sensor bar), while some also use them in more novel ways.

When the GameCube controller for the Switch 2 was first announced, Nintendo warned that it was only compatible with GameCube titles in the Nintendo Switch Online Classics library. The company later clarified that it could be used with any game on the Switch 2, but that issues may arise due to lacking features or buttons found on other controllers. The addition of gyro controls and the C-Button seems to contradict the idea that the controller is designed exclusively for GameCube titles (none of which support gyro input) but consider yourself warned.

The GameCube controller is available to order only for Nintendo Switch Online members, with a limit of one per person. The controller can also be bought in person at select Nintendo stores.

item.title: Summer Game Fest Live 2025: Start Time, How To Watch, And What To Expect

The hype train will keep rolling down the track today with Summer Game Fest Live, the annual showcase hosted by Geoff Keighley.

Summer Game Fest Live 2025 will kick off from the YouTube Theater in Los Angeles, California on June 6 at 2 PM PT / 5 PM ET. Multiple games have already been teased for an appearance at the show, including Mafia: The Old Country, Splitgate 2, and Fortnite.

How to watch Summer Game Fest Live 2025

Summer Game Fest will be available to stream on YouTube and Twitch channels. The show can also be viewed live on X, Facebook, and Steam.

Summer Game Fest Live 2025 start time

Summer Game Fest Live 2025 is scheduled to begin at 2 PM PT / 5 PM ET on Friday, June 6.

  • 2 PM PT
  • 5 PM ET
  • 10 PM BST
  • 7 AM AET (June 7)

What to expect

Teaser posts on social media have confirmed that Summer Game Fest Live 2025 will be a two-hour event. It will be immediately followed by Day of the Devs: Summer Game Fest Live 2025, a separate showcase, highlighting multiple indie games.

Among the confirmed guests for Summer Game Fest Live 2025 are Hideo Kojima, whose next project Death Stranding 2: On The Beach is set to launch June 26, and GameSpot’s own Lucy James, who will be co-hosting the event.

Below is a list of games whose appearance at today’s event has been teased by official social media accounts:

  • A new project called “Ill” from a studio called Team Clout
  • Mafia: The Old Country
  • Splitgate 2
  • Mouse: P.I For Hire
  • Dying Light: The Beast
  • Fortnite

item.title: Black Myth: Wukong Xbox Release Date Is Exactly One Year After PS5
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/black-myth-wukong-xbox-release-date-is-exactly-one-year-after-ps5/1100-6532164/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Black Myth: Wukong, one of 2024's best-selling games worldwide, is finally headed to Xbox after a year of exclusivity on PlayStation. The game is coming to Xbox Series X|S on August 20, with preorders opening on June 18.

The game originally released on PS5 and PC on August 20, 2024, meaning it's coming to Xbox Series X|S precisely one year later. This is fueling the theory that Sony did, in fact, have a one-year exclusivity deal with developer Game Science.

Some had claimed that technical issues with the Xbox Series S prompted a delay for the Xbox version, but Microsoft maintained this was not true (despite the fact that some titles have in the past run into issues with the lower-spec version of the newest Xbox).

In a post on the game's website, Game Science said it took time to bring Black Myth to Xbox because it was "no easy feat" to ensure the experience met the developer's internal expectations. "Fortunately, we were able to complete this challenging task smoothly within the first year of the game's official release," the developer said.

What's more, Game Science has announced the first-ever discount on Black Myth, stating the game will be 20% off beginning June 18 on all platforms. That means Xbox players can preorder the game at a 20% discount, bringing the price down from $60 to about $48.

Black Myth sold 10 million copies in its first three days and has gone on to shift more than 25 million units. At launch, the overwhelming majority of PC sales on Steam came from China, where its developer is based. China is an absolutely massive market for games, with the number of gamers in China exceeding the total US population.

Black Myth has been controversial in some circles. Game Science's guidelines for content creators asked them to avoid discussing "feminist propaganda" and COVID. A report from IGN in 2023 documented the alleged sexist and misogynist commentary from the development team.

If you're just getting started with Black Myth, you can check out GameSpot's Black Myth: Wukong guide that runs through 20 things to know before you jump in. We also have a dedicated guides hub where you can get all the key info you need. GameSpot's Black Myth: Wukong review scored the game an 8/10.
